You can debug when testing methods via the SAP Gateway Client or the SAP Build Action. Set an external breakpoint for the user in your destination that we created at the beginning.

 

 

For the PATCH method, our key fields in the internal table IT_KEY_TAB. 

 

 

8. Create A Joule Skill to Get Purchase Order

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Create->Joule Skill and fill the name and description. Open the created skill.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄôTrigger‚Äô step. On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab fill the name and description. Allow Joule to generate a response and skill to be started directly by user.

 

 

We don't need input, but outputs can vary according to our needs. In this tutorial, the parameters shown below have been added as outputs.

Choose ‚ÄòConfigure‚Äô and add parameters you want to show to the user. For this example, all parameters are string except the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô which is boolean.

 

 

 

Press ‚Äò+‚Äô and choose ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô, ‚ÄòBrowse All Actions‚Äô.

 

 

Search for ‚ÄòZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô or your Service Name. Add the ‚ÄòGet entities from ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST‚Äô.

 

 

Select the ‚ÄòDestination Variable‚Äô as Destination we created. 

 

 

We can skip the input tab because there are no input for GET method.

 

 

We can see the output parameters in this tab.

 

 

On the "End" step, we need to assign the input and output parameters for the skills. Since we don't have any inputs, let's assign the outputs added in the "Trigger" step as our action's outputs.

 

 

Save the Joule Skill.

 

 

And Release.

 

 

Now Deploy.

 

 

Choose the Environment we created and click ‚ÄòUpgrade‚Äô.

 

 

Match the destinations, and the skill will be ready to use by Joule after deployment.

 

 

9. Create A Joule Skill to Approve Purchase Order

 

On the ‚ÄòTrigger‚Äô step, fill the name and description. Deactivate the ‚ÄòAllow Joule to generate a response‚Äô feature because in this skill we will create our own messages. The other feature should be active.

 

 

Configure the input parameters. Add purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem key fields as string. For approve skill we don‚Äôt need any output field.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCall Action‚Äô.

 

 

Browse All Actions.

 

 

Search update or the service name. Add the Update entity in ZSLV_V_BUILD_TEST.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòGeneral‚Äô tab, assign the Destination.

 

 

On the ‚ÄòInputs‚Äô tab, assign the purchaseorder, purchaseorderitem and reservationitem to the parameters created on the "Trigger" step.

 

 

We only need to fill the fields ‚Äòapproved‚Äô from the fields to be updated. We need to configure the ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field because action inputs can only be string. 

 

Choose ‚Äòapproved‚Äô field and ‚ÄòApply a formula‚Äô.

 

Type ‚Äòtrue‚Äô and click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô.

 

 

Choose ‚Äò+‚Äô and ‚ÄòCheck Condition‚Äô.

 

 

Choose the ‚ÄòCondition Editor‚Äô.

 

 

Add the following conditions and Click ‚ÄòApply‚Äô. If PATCH method is executed successfully, the result will be empty. 

 

 

If the condition is met, the left branch of the condition executes. In the opposite case, the ‚ÄòDefault‚Äô branch of the condition executes.

 

Choose the ‚Äò+‚Äô on the left branch and ‚ÄòSend Response‚Äô.

 

 

Open Message Editor.

 

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

You can add parameters to the title and message with the ‚Äò<>‚Äô button.

 

 

Do the same steps for the right branch of the condition. ‚Äò+‚Äô -> ‚ÄôSend Response‚Äô -> ‚ÄòOpen Message Editor‚Äô

 

Fill the parameters as shown below and save.

 

 

Save, Release and Deploy just like the previous GET_PURCHASE_ORDER skill.

 

10. Launch The Joule and Test The Skills

 

Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Control Tower->Environments->Joule

 

 

Launch the joule, ask for Purchase Orders and get the details.

 

 

Ask joule to approve the purchase orders and get the illustrated success message card we create.

entry.title: How to Use SAP Extensibility Wizard in SAP S/4HANA Clean Core
entry.content:
A Comprehensive Guide to Extending SAP S/4HANA with the SAP Extensibility Wizard ‚Äî Without Compromising Your Clean Core

Introduction

Extensibility is a critical aspect of SAP S/4HANA, enabling organizations to tailor the system to their unique business needs while maintaining stability and upgrade readiness. In this guide, we will explore the SAP Extensibility Wizard, a powerful tool designed to help developers extend SAP S/4HANA in a clean and controlled way.

What Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard?

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a guided tool provided by SAP that simplifies the process of creating extensions. It ensures that developers can add custom functionality without modifying the core system, thereby preserving the clean core principle. This approach guarantees that upgrades remain smooth and that the system stays resilient over time.

Availability: Public Cloud vs. Private Cloud

A common question arises: Is the SAP Extensibility Wizard available only in the Public Cloud, or also in the Private Cloud?

  • Public Cloud (SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì Public Edition):
    The wizard is primarily available here. It supports clean-core extensibility and helps organizations build safe, upgrade‚Äëfriendly extensions.
  • Private Cloud / On‚ÄëPremise:
    Extensibility is possible through other approaches such as in‚Äëapp extensibility, ABAP Cloud, and side‚Äëby‚Äëside extensions on SAP BTP. However, the wizard itself is not provided in the same way as in the Public Cloud.

In summary:

  • Public Cloud ‚Üí Wizard available.
  • Private Cloud / On‚ÄëPremise ‚Üí Extensibility options exist, but without the wizard.

Focus of This Blog

This blog will focus on the SAP Extensibility Wizard for SAP S/4HANA Cloud ‚Äì Public Edition.

How to Use the Extensibility Wizard

With the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition extensibility wizard, developers can:

  • Create on‚Äëstack extensions such as custom fields and custom logic.
  • Build side‚Äëby‚Äëside extensions like custom processes using SAP Build Process Automation.

This guided approach ensures that extensions are implemented efficiently, securely, and in alignment with SAP‚Äôs clean‚Äëcore strategy.

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard is a key enabler for organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. By leveraging this tool, businesses can extend their systems with confidence, ensuring that customizations remain upgrade‚Äësafe and future‚Äëproof.

 

Detailed Steps:

Use Case : We will create a sales order approval process .

1. Navigate to SAP S4/HANA Fiori Launchpad.

1.1 Select Business Application Manage Sales Orders. 

1.2  Navigate to Create Extension

 

1.3 In this case , we will select custom process.

The process can start based on various triggers 

1.4 Select Business Event from SAP S4/HANA, that Triggers the process

1.5 Select Event Object

1.6 Select the SalesOrder create event.

1.7 Click Preview to see all the options you selected on previous screens, and make any necessary corrections.

1.8 Click Create , to create the process in SAP Build.

1.9 The extension is now available and can also be opened in SAP Build.

1.10 When you select Open Extension, the system launches another tab that opens the process.

1.11 The Process Automation project overview page is now displayed. Select SalesOrder Approval.

1.12 Extension is now openEd in SAP Build , Start design of the process.

The Business context is carried over from SAP S4/HANA to SAP Build .

1.13 You can add an action, form , or approval . To get further details on the sales order, you need to call an action .

1.14 In this use case , we will call sales order read API , to fetch the sales order details.

1.15 Browse the library to search for  the relevant APIs .

1.16 Select read sales order API to get details of the sales order, The business context and system ID were automatically pulled in from SAP S4/HANA .

1.17 The action to read the sales order has now been added . Now users can design the process according to their needs. The user now wants to initiate a workflow that sends an email to the approver for sales order approval .

1.18 The email will include the sales order details , allowing approver to review and approve it . we're utilizing AI to generate the process , Enter the prompt to add an approval step and send the sales order details to the approver via email.

1.19 AI has now added the process step to read the sales order and email, The sales order details to the approver .

 

Conclusion

The SAP Extensibility Wizard empowers organizations running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to extend their systems safely and efficiently, without compromising the clean core. By leveraging guided tools for custom fields, logic, and side‚Äëby‚Äëside processes, businesses can innovate while staying upgrade‚Äëready.

Extensibility in SAP is not just about adding features‚Äîit‚Äôs about doing so in a way that keeps your system future‚Äëproof. With the wizard, you can confidently build the extensions your business needs today, while ensuring smooth upgrades tomorrow.

entry.title: How to Create a ServiceNow Incident via REST API Using ABAP (OAuth 2.0)
entry.content:
Prerequisites

  • ServiceNow instance access with API credentials (Client ID, Client Secret)
  • SAP NetWeaver with HTTP Client (CL_HTTP_CLIENT) and JSON support (/UI2/CL_JSON)

Step 1: Obtain OAuth2 Token from ServiceNow

First, you need to POST your client credentials to ServiceNow‚Äôs /oauth_token endpoint to get a bearer token. This token authorizes subsequent API calls.

ABAP Code:

FORM get_servicenow_token USING iv_token_url TYPE string
                              iv_client_id TYPE string
                              iv_client_secret TYPE string
                         CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
                                  cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, the access_token can now be used as a Bearer token.

Step 2: Build the JSON Payload

Create a JSON structure that describes the incident.

ABAP Code:

lv_json_body =
'{' &&
'"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
'"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
'"category":"Data",' &&
'"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
'"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
'"impact":"2",' &&
'"urgency":"2"' &&
'}'.

Step 3: Create the Incident via POST API

Now, make a POST request to the ServiceNow incident table, including your access token for authorization.

ABAP Code:

FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.
ENDFORM.

If successful, cv_result will contain the incident response from ServiceNow.

Step 4: Combine the Steps in Your Report

Your main program calls these subroutines in sequence.

Example Main Logic:

* Get the access token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token
               USING lv_token_url
                     lv_client_id
                     lv_client_secret
               CHANGING ls_token
                     lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Create the incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident
                    USING lv_post_url
                          ls_token-access_token
                          lv_json_body
                   CHANGING lv_result
                            lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.

Final Notes

  • Security: Never hardcode sensitive data in productive programs‚Äîuse secure storage.
  • Error Handling: Always add robust error handling and log failures for troubleshooting.
  • Data Mapping: Adjust JSON fields based on ServiceNow table and your organization‚Äôs requirements.

Conclusion

Integrating SAP and ServiceNow allows you to automatically manage ITSM incidents directly from SAP ABAP.  The above example demonstrates OAuth token retrieval and incident creation using ABAP.  Adapt and build on this foundation to suit your business requirements.

Happy Integrating! Let me know in the comments if you have any questions or need clarification on any step.

 

Complete ABAP CODE:

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Report ZSNOW
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Utility: ServiceNow Incident API Integration
*---------------------------------------------------------------------*

REPORT zsnow.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token,
         access_token TYPE string,
         scope        TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
       END OF ty_token.

DATA: lv_token_url     TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/oauth_token',
      lv_client_id     TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-id...',
      lv_client_secret TYPE string VALUE '...your-client-secret...',
      lv_post_url      TYPE string VALUE 'https://://<your-comapny-domain>.service-now.com/api/now/table/incident',
      lv_json_body     TYPE string,
      ls_token         TYPE ty_token,
      lv_err           TYPE string,
      lv_result        TYPE string.

* Prepare JSON Body

lv_json_body = '{' &&
               '"caller_id":"ABC Corp",' &&
               '"service_offering":"SAP Material",' &&
               '"category":"Data",' &&
               '"subcategory":"Incorrect Data",' &&
               '"short_description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"description":"Test Incident from SAP",' &&
               '"impact":"2",' &&
               '"urgency":"2"' &&
               '}'.

* Step 1: Get the Token
PERFORM get_servicenow_token USING lv_token_url
                                   lv_client_id
                                   lv_client_secret
                          CHANGING ls_token
                                   lv_err.

IF lv_err IS NOT INITIAL OR ls_token-access_token IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Token Error:', lv_err.
  EXIT.
ENDIF.

* Step 2: Create Incident
PERFORM create_servicenow_incident USING lv_post_url
                                         ls_token-access_token
                                         lv_json_body
                                CHANGING lv_result
                                         lv_err.

IF lv_err IS INITIAL.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Response:', lv_result.
ELSE.
  WRITE: / 'Incident Creation Error:', lv_err.
ENDIF.



*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Get OAuth Token from ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM get_servicenow_token
  USING    iv_token_url TYPE string
           iv_client_id TYPE string
           iv_client_secret TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_token TYPE ty_token
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lv_payload     TYPE string,
        lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
        lv_response    TYPE string,
        lt_token       TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_token,
        lo_json        TYPE REF TO /ui2/cl_json.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_token.

  lv_payload = |grant_type=client_credentials&client_id={ iv_client_id }&client_secret={ iv_client_secret }|.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_token_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client
    EXCEPTIONS
      OTHERS = 1.

  IF sy-subrc <> 0 OR lo_http_client IS INITIAL.
    cv_errmsg = 'Failed to create HTTP client for token.'.
    EXIT.
  ENDIF.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/x-www-form-urlencoded' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      lv_response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
      CONCATENATE '[' lv_response ']' INTO lv_response.

      CREATE OBJECT lo_json.
      lo_json->deserialize( EXPORTING json = lv_response CHANGING data = lt_token ).
      IF lt_token IS NOT INITIAL.
        READ TABLE lt_token INDEX 1 INTO cv_token.
      ELSE.
        cv_errmsg = 'Could not parse token from JSON.'.
      ENDIF.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " get_servicenow_token

*--------------------------------------------------------*
* Create an Incident in ServiceNow
*--------------------------------------------------------*
FORM create_servicenow_incident
  USING iv_post_url TYPE string
        iv_access_token TYPE string
        iv_body TYPE string
  CHANGING cv_result TYPE string
           cv_errmsg TYPE string.

  DATA: lo_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client.

  CLEAR: cv_errmsg, cv_result.

  CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
    EXPORTING
      url    = iv_post_url
    IMPORTING
      client = lo_http_client.

  lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = |Bearer { iv_access_token }| ).
  lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( iv_body ).

  TRY.
      lo_http_client->send( ).
      lo_http_client->receive( ).
      cv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
      lo_http_client->close( ).
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx_err).
      cv_errmsg = lx_err->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

ENDFORM.                    " create_servicenow_incident
